news_header: U.S. crude oil inventories rose significantly, exceeding expectations, while gasoline inventories increased slightly.
news_original_title: U.S. Crude Oil Inventories Surge Much More Than Expected
news_text: The Energy Information Administration reported a substantial increase in U.S. crude oil inventories, which rose by 8.7 million barrels for the week ending January 31, surpassing economists' expectations of a 3.2 million barrel increase. Current inventories stand at 423.8 million barrels, about 5% below the five-year average. Gasoline inventories also saw a rise of 2.2 million barrels, while distillate fuel inventories fell by 5.5 million barrels, remaining approximately 12% below the five-year average.
